Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 84, S.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of care to maintain the sidewalk in a safe condition under Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 84, Section 15.

Feliciano v. Rosemar Silver Co., 401 Mas.raw_text: Feliciano v. Rosemar Silver Co., 401 Mass. 141 (1987)
Feliciano v. Rosemar Silver Co., 401 Mas.proposition: (Discussion on property owner's duty to maintain sidewalks).
Feliciano v. Rosemar Silver Co., 401 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether an unmarried cohabitant may recover for loss of consortium and holds that consortium claims are limited to spouses. It does not discuss premises liability, sidewalks, or any duty of a property owner to maintain sidewalks. Therefore it does not support a proposition about a property owner’s duty to maintain sidewalks.
Feliciano v. Rosemar Silver Co., 401 Mas.relevant_excerpt:
The question on appeal is whether, in those circumstances, the plaintiff may recover for loss of consortium. We answer that question in the negative.

… Our recognition of a right of recovery for the loss of a spouse’s consortium … promotes that value. Conversely, that value would be subverted by our recognition of a right to recover for loss of consortium by a person who has not accepted the correlative responsibilities of marriage.

Scheffel v. Krane, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 630.raw_text: Scheffel v. Krane, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 630 (1986)
Scheffel v. Krane, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 630.proposition: (Case addressing liability for injuries resulting from icy conditions on a sidewalk).
Scheffel v. Krane, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 630.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns criminal convictions for aggravated rape and focuses on evidentiary rulings (prior false accusations, rape-shield issues) and jury instructions, not premises liability or injuries from icy sidewalk conditions. There is no discussion of tort law, landowner duty, or sidewalk ice, so it does not support a proposition about liability for icy sidewalk injuries. The citation appears to be to an entirely different case than the one whose text is provided.
Scheffel v. Krane, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 630.relevant_excerpt: As a result of an incident that occurred in February of 1983, Thomas E. Blair, Leslie D. Caldwell, Jr., Richard J. Higgins, and Donald B. Walsh were all convicted on indictments that charged them with aggravated rape. On appeal, they contend that the judge improperly excluded evidence of a prior false allegation of sexual abuse allegedly made by the victim. In addition, they find fault with his instructions to the jury. We affirm the convictions.

Kohlfuss v. Ceppetelli, 2002 Mass. App..raw_text: Kohlfuss v. Ceppetelli, 2002 Mass. App. Div. 105 (2002)
Kohlfuss v. Ceppetelli, 2002 Mass. App..proposition: (Case discussing property owner's duty to prevent hazardous conditions).
Kohlfuss v. Ceppetelli, 2002 Mass. App..case_name: Cummings Properties, LLC v. Nardone Enterprises, Inc.
Kohlfuss v. Ceppetelli, 2002 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with procedural issues surrounding a default judgment in a commercial summary process (eviction) action and the standards for relief from judgment under Mass. R. Civ. P. 60(b). It does not address premises liability, hazardous conditions, or any duty of a property owner to prevent hazardous conditions. Using this case for that proposition would therefore be inaccurate and out of context.
Kohlfuss v. Ceppetelli, 2002 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “There is no existing case authority interpreting Uniform Summary Process Rule 10(d)(iii). We conclude that, contrary to the defendants’ suggestion, the Rule cannot be reasonably construed as voiding an otherwise valid default judgment issued after proper service and actual notice to a defendant-tenant… In short, there is nothing in Rule 10(d)(iii) which entitled the defendants in this case to relief from judgment pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P., Rule 60(b)(4).”

Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority,.raw_text: Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority, 442 Mass. 476 (2004)
Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority,.proposition: (Liability for failure to maintain safe premises).
Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority,.case_name: Local 1652, International Ass'n of Firefighters v. Town of Framingham
Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns public-sector labor law and municipal budgeting duties under G.L. c. 150E and the Proposition 2½ override statute, not tort or premises liability. It addresses a town’s obligation to submit an unconditional funding request for a staffing provision in a collective bargaining agreement, not liability for failure to maintain safe premises. Therefore it does not support a proposition about premises liability or failure to maintain safe property conditions.
Sullivan v. Brookline Housing Authority,.relevant_excerpt: “Given the plain language of G. L. c. 150E, § 7 (b), and this case history, we conclude that the town was required to submit a budget that unconditionally and fully funded the staffing provision.… The plain language of par. (m) does not authorize town officials to submit a budget contingent on an override. There is no merit in any of the arguments advanced by the town to the effect that the override statute nevertheless changes the obligation of town officials to submit a proposal for full funding of the staffing provision under G. L. c. 150E, § 7 (b).”

Doherty v. Galena, 407 Mass. 415 (1990).proposition: (Regarding the duty of care owed to individuals on property).
Doherty v. Galena, 407 Mass. 415 (1990).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about joinder, evidentiary issues, expert testimony, continuances, and ineffective assistance in a prosecution of a physician for sexual assaults on patients. It does not discuss premises liability, landowner obligations, or any duty of care owed to individuals on property. Therefore it does not provide authority on the duty of care issue referenced in the proposition.

Gore v. Balsam Gardens, Inc., 9 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Gore v. Balsam Gardens, Inc., 9 Mass. App. Ct. 869 (1980)
Gore v. Balsam Gardens, Inc., 9 Mass. Ap.proposition: (Negligence in failing to maintain safe conditions).

Rodrigues v. Newton Housing Authority, 9.raw_text: Rodrigues v. Newton Housing Authority, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 762 (2019)
Rodrigues v. Newton Housing Authority, 9.proposition: (Discussion on the duty of care owed to individuals entering premises).
Rodrigues v. Newton Housing Authority, 9.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal case involving constructive possession, armed home invasion, firearm charges, and malicious destruction of property. It does not analyze premises liability, invitee/licensee status, or any duty of care owed by a property owner or occupier to persons entering the premises. Because there is no discussion of a civil duty of care standard for entrants onto land, the case does not support the stated proposition.
Rodrigues v. Newton Housing Authority, 9.relevant_excerpt: In order to convict the defendant of [armed home invasion], the Commonwealth was required to establish that: "[T]he defendant (1) 'knowingly enter[ed] the dwelling place of another'; (2) 'knowing or having reason to know that one or more persons are present within' ...; (3) 'while armed with a dangerous weapon'; and (4) 'use[d] force or threaten[ed] the imminent use of force upon any person within such dwelling place whether or not injury occur[red], or intentionally cause[d] any injury to any person within such dwelling place.'" (This addresses elements of a crime, not civil duty of care.)

Perna v. F.W. Jones Company, 2 Mass. App.raw_text: Perna v. F.W. Jones Company, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 624 (1974)
Perna v. F.W. Jones Company, 2 Mass. App.proposition: (Liability for failure to correct hazardous conditions).
Perna v. F.W. Jones Company, 2 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The case concerns an executor’s contractual and fiduciary obligations in a real estate sale and his personal liability for breaching a purchase-and-sale agreement. It does not involve premises liability, dangerous or hazardous physical conditions, or a failure to correct such conditions. The holding is about enforceability of the executor’s contract and the effect of a probate license, not liability for failing to remedy hazards, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Perna v. F.W. Jones Company, 2 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “The fiduciary duty of an executor or administrator is separate and distinct from the contractual duty he may incur when he enters into agreements with third persons. The first is owed to and enforceable by the beneficiaries of the estate, while the second is owed to and enforceable by a stranger to the estate. And, with a few exceptions not here material… an executor or administrator is liable on contracts he makes for the benefit of the estate, if at all, individually and not in his representative capacity.”

Pressley v. Reardon, 1 Mass. App. Ct. 63.raw_text: Pressley v. Reardon, 1 Mass. App. Ct. 639 (1973)
Pressley v. Reardon, 1 Mass. App. Ct. 63.proposition: (Negligence resulting in injury on an unkept sidewalk).
Pressley v. Reardon, 1 Mass. App. Ct. 63.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a land registration and boundary dispute over how to measure a parcel’s boundary from a public way (Main Street). It does not discuss negligence, personal injury, or conditions of a sidewalk, nor any duty to maintain a sidewalk. Therefore it provides no support for a proposition about negligence resulting in injury on an unkept sidewalk.
Pressley v. Reardon, 1 Mass. App. Ct. 63.relevant_excerpt: "We fail to see how this case is distinguishable in any material way from that of Dodd v. Witt, 139 Mass. 63 (1885), where the court considered the precise question involved in this case: 'A majority of the court is of opinion, that it is a common method of measurement in the country, where the boundary is a stream or way, to measure from the bank of the stream or the side of the way; and that there is a reasonable presumption that the measurements were made in this way, unless something appears affirmatively in the deed to show that they began at the centre line of the stream or way' (emphasis supplied)."
